Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of the afternoon pressing in. My daughter had called twice already, reminding me not to be late for the family gathering. My grandkids had been looking forward to this for weeks, and I promised them I’d be there early to help set up the grill. But as I stood at the polling station, ballot envelope in hand, the poll worker frowned and pointed out the smudge on my signature. “I’m sorry, sir, but you’ll need to re-sign this so your vote counts,” she said gently. I could see the line behind me growing, and I knew that re-signing meant more paperwork, more waiting. My phone buzzed again—another message from my daughter. I felt torn. As a grandfather, I wanted to keep my promise and be present for my family. As a voter, I felt a duty to follow the rules and ensure my ballot was valid. The expectations pulled at me from both sides, and I stood there, pen in hand, heart pounding, caught between the two worlds that mattered most to me.
